elements.content: Zeolitic cluster organic frameworks constructed with two different tetrahedral units, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and hmt-type [Cu4Cl6]2– clusters, are realized in this work for the first time. By using a tetrahedral hmt ligand to assemble in situ hmt-type Cu4Cl6 clusters, a three-dimensional cluster organic framework with lonsdaleite (lon) topology is successfully built to host the two-dimensional honeycomb-like metal–organic complex. Furthermore, a series of cluster organic frameworks based on hmt and other well-defined copper-halide clusters, such as Cu2Cl3, Cu3Cl2, Cu4Cl4, Cu5Cl6, and Cu6Cl6, are also presented, which exhibit rich topological nets. These compounds are further investigated by infrared, powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, infrared and photoluminescent spectroscopy. Photoluminescent studies reveal that these compounds display yellow green emissions based on halide to metal charge transfer. This work reveals a versatile synthetic method to generate a large family of copper-halide cluster organic frameworks with hmt ligands.
elements.clean_text: Zeolitic cluster organic frameworks constructed with two different tetrahedral units, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and hmt-type [Cu4Cl6]2- clusters, are realized in this work for the first time. By using a tetrahedral hmt ligand to assemble in situ hmt-type Cu4Cl6 clusters, a three-dimensional cluster organic framework with lonsdaleite (lon) topology is successfully built to host the two-dimensional honeycomb-like metal-organic complex. Furthermore, a series of cluster organic frameworks based on hmt and other well-defined copper-halide clusters, such as Cu2Cl3, Cu3Cl2, Cu4Cl4, Cu5Cl6, and Cu6Cl6, are also presented, which exhibit rich topological nets. These compounds are further investigated by infrared, powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, infrared and photoluminescent spectroscopy. Photoluminescent studies reveal that these compounds display yellow green emissions based on halide to metal charge transfer. This work reveals a versatile synthetic method to generate a large family of copper-halide cluster organic frameworks with hmt ligands.

elements.content:
Zeolitic cluster organic frameworks constructed with two different tetrahedral units, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and hmt-type [Cu4Cl6]2− cluster, are realized in this work for the first time.

Introduction

Crystalline porous materials, such as zeolites and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), have received much attention because of their multiple functionalities and topologies. A fundamental strategy for the construction of zeolitic materials is based on four-connected inorganic tetrahedral nodes (e.g., Si4+) cross-linked by a bi-coordinated bridge (e.g., O2– as in SiO2, 4 + 2 synthetic strategy). This structure feature can be replaced by metal cations and organic ligands to construct zeolitic MOFs. An exemplar is the well-known zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) which were constructed by tetrahedrally coordinated divalent cations (M2+ = Zn2+ or Co2+) and uninegative imidazolate ligands. Inversely, it is also useful that the organic molecules act as tetrahedral nodes and the metal centers act as linkers. The hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) molecule contains four nitrogen atoms in a tetrahedral arrangement, making it a potential organic tetrahedral node. For example, a zeotype material with MTN topology was constructed from the hmt ligands via the 2-connected trigonal bipyramidal Cd­(II) cations. Another useful strategy is the connection of inorganic and organic tetrahedral nodes through direct coordination interaction (4 + 4 strategy). It is well established by the boron imidazolate frameworks (BIFs) based on presynthesized four-connected boron imidazolate ligands and four-connected unicharged metal ions (Li+ or Cu+).
elements.clean_text:
Zeolitic cluster organic frameworks constructed with two different tetrahedral units, hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) and hmt-type [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster, are realized in this work for the first time.

Introduction

Crystalline porous materials, such as zeolites and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), have received much attention because of their multiple functionalities and topologies. A fundamental strategy for the construction of zeolitic materials is based on four-connected inorganic tetrahedral nodes (e.g., Si4+) cross-linked by a bi-coordinated bridge (e.g., O2- as in SiO2, 4 + 2 synthetic strategy). This structure feature can be replaced by metal cations and organic ligands to construct zeolitic MOFs. An exemplar is the well-known zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) which were constructed by tetrahedrally coordinated divalent cations (M2+ = Zn2+ or Co2+) and uninegative imidazolate ligands. Inversely, it is also useful that the organic molecules act as tetrahedral nodes and the metal centers act as linkers. The hexamethylenetetramine (hmt) molecule contains four nitrogen atoms in a tetrahedral arrangement, making it a potential organic tetrahedral node. For example, a zeotype material with MTN topology was constructed from the hmt ligands via the 2-connected trigonal bipyramidal Cd(II) cations. Another useful strategy is the connection of inorganic and organic tetrahedral nodes through direct coordination interaction (4 + 4 strategy). It is well established by the boron imidazolate frameworks (BIFs) based on presynthesized four-connected boron imidazolate ligands and four-connected unicharged metal ions (Li+ or Cu+).

elements.content: The other element for constructing zeolitic MOFs is to utilize 4-connected inorganic building units. Except for direct employment of 4-connected metal centers (Zn2+, Co2+), the replacement of metal center with clusters has been proven with the potential to produce multifunctional zeolitic materials, which endow the materials with unique catalytic performances and the possibility of introducing additional functionalities. A representative example is copper halide clusters which have been extensively used for syntheses of MOFs; however, rare structures with zeolitic topologies are known. Recently, we have successfully prepared one MTN-type and one SOD-type framework by using linear 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane (dbo) as linkers and Cu4I4 (or Cu3I4) clusters as 4-connected nodes. However, because of the multiple forms and structural diversity of copper-halide clusters, it still remains a great challenge to prepare copper-halide clusters based zeolitic materials.
elements.clean_text: The other element for constructing zeolitic MOFs is to utilize 4-connected inorganic building units. Except for direct employment of 4-connected metal centers (Zn2+, Co2+), the replacement of metal center with clusters has been proven with the potential to produce multifunctional zeolitic materials, which endow the materials with unique catalytic performances and the possibility of introducing additional functionalities. A representative example is copper halide clusters which have been extensively used for syntheses of MOFs; however, rare structures with zeolitic topologies are known. Recently, we have successfully prepared one MTN-type and one SOD-type framework by using linear 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dbo) as linkers and Cu4I4 (or Cu3I4) clusters as 4-connected nodes. However, because of the multiple forms and structural diversity of copper-halide clusters, it still remains a great challenge to prepare copper-halide clusters based zeolitic materials.

elements.content: In this work, we develop a new synthetic strategy for zeolitic cluster organic frameworks by combining two tetrahedral units (), the organic hmt ligand and pure inorganic hmt-like [Cu4Cl6]2– cluster. Here, we report an outstanding compound, namely, [Cu4Cl6(μ4-hmt)]­[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ3-hmt)]­·(H2O)3 (1), which contains two independent frameworks: a three-dimensional (3D) cluster organic framework with 4-connected lon topology based on such two tetrahedral units and a two-dimensional (2D) Cu­(I) coordination polymer. The 2D coordination network is located in the pores of the 3D framework, which plays a structure-directing role. Furthermore, by systematic adjustment of the reaction conditions, a series of cluster organic frameworks () based on distinct and well-defined Cu–Cl clusters (shown in Figure s1) were also obtained, which exhibit rich structural features and topologies.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we develop a new synthetic strategy for zeolitic cluster organic frameworks by combining two tetrahedral units (), the organic hmt ligand and pure inorganic hmt-like [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster. Here, we report an outstanding compound, namely, [Cu4Cl6(μ4-hmt)][Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ3-hmt)]⋅(H2O)3 (1), which contains two independent frameworks: a three-dimensional (3D) cluster organic framework with 4-connected lon topology based on such two tetrahedral units and a two-dimensional (2D) Cu(I) coordination polymer. The 2D coordination network is located in the pores of the 3D framework, which plays a structure-directing role. Furthermore, by systematic adjustment of the reaction conditions, a series of cluster organic frameworks () based on distinct and well-defined Cu-Cl clusters (shown in Figure s1) were also obtained, which exhibit rich structural features and topologies.

R 1 = Σ­(|F o| – |F c|)/Σ|F o|, wR 2 = [Σw(F o 2 – F c 2)2/Σw(F o 2)2]0.5.

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. All syntheses were carried out in a 20 mL vial under autogenous pressure. All powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05° (see Figures s6–s9). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere (see Figure s10). Elemental analyses (EA) for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS0 CE elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were taken on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT–IR spectrometer in the 4000–400 cm–1 region by using KBr pellets. Steady-state photoluminescence spectra were performed by using an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrometer equipped with a continuous Xe 900 xenon lamp.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. All syntheses were carried out in a 20 mL vial under autogenous pressure. All powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax2500 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05° (see Figures s6-s9). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out with a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851e analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere (see Figure s10). Elemental analyses (EA) for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS0 CE elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were taken on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region by using KBr pellets. Steady-state photoluminescence spectra were performed by using an Edinburgh FLS920 spectrometer equipped with a continuous Xe 900 xenon lamp.

elements.content: A mixture of hmt (0.069 g, 0.5 mol), CuCl (0.098 g, 1.0 mmol), n-butanol (4.0 mL), and NH3·H2O (2.0 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL vial at 120 °C for 4 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-yellow crystals of 1 were obtained (Yield: 60%). IR (KBr cm–1): 3450 (m), 3243 (w), 2970 (w), 2888 (w), 1623 (w), 1463 (m), 1227 (s), 1005 (s), 693 (m), 650 (w). Elemental analysis for C12H31Cl6Cu7N8O4 (%): Calcd: C, 14.47; H, 3.09; N, 11.25. Found: C, 15.05; H, 3.18; N, 12.61.

Synthesis of [Cu4Cl6(hmt)][Cu3(OH)(hmt)](H2O)3 (1)

A mixture of hmt (0.069 g, 0.5 mol), CuCl (0.098 g, 1.0 mmol), n-butanol (4.0 mL), and NH3⋅H2O (2.0 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL vial at 120 °C for 4 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-yellow crystals of 1 were obtained (Yield: 60%). IR (KBr cm-1): 3450 (m), 3243 (w), 2970 (w), 2888 (w), 1623 (w), 1463 (m), 1227 (s), 1005 (s), 693 (m), 650 (w). Elemental analysis for C12H31Cl6Cu7N8O4 (%): Calcd: C, 14.47; H, 3.09; N, 11.25. Found: C, 15.05; H, 3.18; N, 12.61.

Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: 60%). IR (KBr cm–1): 3430 (w), 2984 (w), 2960 (w), 2890 (w), 1659 (w), 1453 (m), 1372 (w), 1235 (s), 1028 (s), 706 (m), 669 (m). Pale, colorless block crystals of 4 were obtained just sufficient for a single crystal X-ray structure determination.

A mixture of hmt (0.069 g, 0.5 mmol), CuCl (0.095 g, 1.0 mmol), n-butanol (4.0 mL), and NH3⋅H2O (0.28 mL) were placed in a 20 mL vial at 100 °C for 12 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 5 were obtained (yield: 30%). IR (KBr cm-1): 3315 (m), 3236 (w), 2968 (w), 2884 (w), 2035 (m), 1607 (w), 1463 (m), 1366 (w), 1242 (s), 1180 (m), 1010 (s), 703 (m), 664 (m). elements.content: It is interesting that the syntheses of compounds 1 and 3–5 are similar, while the formation of different structures is dependent on a slight change in the amount of ammonia. The maximum amount of ammonia (2.0 mL) is essential for the synthesis of 1, which reveals that maybe a low pH value is an important factor for the formation of zeolitic structure. Solvent also plays an important role in the reactions. Other different alcohols including methanol, ethanol, and propanol were used as the solvents; only compound 2 was obtained in methanol. It is noted that an attempt of using copper bromide and iodide as the inorganic building centers was also been made; no crystalline product was obtained. These results show both the pH and solvents exert a crucial influence on the formation of different products in similar experimental conditions.
elements.clean_text: It is interesting that the syntheses of compounds 1 and 3-5 are similar, while the formation of different structures is dependent on a slight change in the amount of ammonia. The maximum amount of ammonia (2.0 mL) is essential for the synthesis of 1, which reveals that maybe a low pH value is an important factor for the formation of zeolitic structure. Solvent also plays an important role in the reactions. Other different alcohols including methanol, ethanol, and propanol were used as the solvents; only compound 2 was obtained in methanol. It is noted that an attempt of using copper bromide and iodide as the inorganic building centers was also been made; no crystalline product was obtained. These results show both the pH and solvents exert a crucial influence on the formation of different products in similar experimental conditions.

elements.content: Single-crystal structural determination. Suitable single crystals of compounds 1–5 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Crystallographic data of 1 and 2 were collected on a Mercury single crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Crystallographic data of 3 and 4 were collected on a SuperNova (Cu) single crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) at room temperature. Crystallographic data of 5 was collected on an Oxford Xcalibur Eos diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2. The structures 1–5 were solved by using the program package SHELX-2014/7. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms bond C were generated geometrically. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for 1–5 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal structural determination. Suitable single crystals of compounds 1-5 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Crystallographic data of 1 and 2 were collected on a Mercury single crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Crystallographic data of 3 and 4 were collected on a SuperNova (Cu) single crystal diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromatic Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) at room temperature. Crystallographic data of 5 was collected on an Oxford Xcalibur Eos diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2. The structures 1-5 were solved by using the program package SHELX-2014/7. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms bond C were generated geometrically. Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for 1-5 are summarized in .

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in a hexagonal space group P63 mc. The asymmetric unit contains three unique Cu atoms, two hmt molecules, and one μ3-OH– (Figure s2). One hmt ligand coordinates to four Cu atoms, and another hmt coordinates to three Cu atoms. Interestingly, four Cu atoms are bridged by six Cl atoms to produce an anionic [Cu4Cl6]2– cluster (a), in which the Cu and Cl atoms just mimic the N and C atoms in hmt. So this [Cu4Cl6]2– subunit can be considered as the pure inorganic hmt-like cluster.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structures

Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that 1 crystallizes in a hexagonal space group P63 mc. The asymmetric unit contains three unique Cu atoms, two hmt molecules, and one μ3-OH- (Figure s2). One hmt ligand coordinates to four Cu atoms, and another hmt coordinates to three Cu atoms. Interestingly, four Cu atoms are bridged by six Cl atoms to produce an anionic [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster (a), in which the Cu and Cl atoms just mimic the N and C atoms in hmt. So this [Cu4Cl6]2- subunit can be considered as the pure inorganic hmt-like cluster.

elements.content: (a) The 4-connected [Cu4Cl6]2– cluster; (b) the 4-connected hmt ligand; (c) the lon cage constructed by six [Cu4Cl6]2– clusters and six hmt ligands; (d) the 3-connected hmt ligand; (e) the 3-connected Cu3O unit; (f) view of the 3-connected layer; (g) the 3D framework penetrated by 2D layer along the a-axis; (h) topology of the 3D framework penetrated by a 2D layer. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The 4-connected [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster; (b) the 4-connected hmt ligand; (c) the lon cage constructed by six [Cu4Cl6]2- clusters and six hmt ligands; (d) the 3-connected hmt ligand; (e) the 3-connected Cu3O unit; (f) view of the 3-connected layer; (g) the 3D framework penetrated by 2D layer along the a-axis; (h) topology of the 3D framework penetrated by a 2D layer. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The most striking structural feature of compound 1 is the presence of two independent frameworks: a [Cu4Cl6]2– cluster-based 3D framework and a mononuclear Cu based 2D network. The [Cu4Cl6]2– cluster-based framework is generated by strictly alternating [Cu4Cl6]2– clusters and hmt molecule (c). By regarding these building units as four-connected nodes (a,b), this framework could be treated as a 4-connected network with a lonsdaleite (lon) topology (h). The mononuclear Cu based network is built up from μ3-OH– and μ3-hmt connnected by Cu atoms. Each μ3-OH– is connected to three Cu atoms to form a Cu3O unit (e). This unit is connected to three hmt molecules. Then each hmt is connected to three Cu3O units. Such connection generates infinite layers parallel to the ab plane (f). These layers have an hcb topology. They are stacked along the c-axis in an ABAB sequence. The hcb-type 2D network and the lon-type 3D network interpenetrate into a final framework (g,h). There is no obvious interaction between two different networks.
elements.clean_text: The most striking structural feature of compound 1 is the presence of two independent frameworks: a [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster-based 3D framework and a mononuclear Cu based 2D network. The [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster-based framework is generated by strictly alternating [Cu4Cl6]2- clusters and hmt molecule (c). By regarding these building units as four-connected nodes (a,b), this framework could be treated as a 4-connected network with a lonsdaleite (lon) topology (h). The mononuclear Cu based network is built up from μ3-OH- and μ3-hmt connnected by Cu atoms. Each μ3-OH- is connected to three Cu atoms to form a Cu3O unit (e). This unit is connected to three hmt molecules. Then each hmt is connected to three Cu3O units. Such connection generates infinite layers parallel to the ab plane (f). These layers have an hcb topology. They are stacked along the c-axis in an ABAB sequence. The hcb-type 2D network and the lon-type 3D network interpenetrate into a final framework (g,h). There is no obvious interaction between two different networks.

elements.content: The single-crystal structure analysis shows that compound 2 includes two different types of CuCl clusters. Similar to 1, four Cu atoms are bridged by six Cl atoms to produce a [Cu4Cl6]2– cluster, and then three chloride atoms chelate to another Cu3 atom to form the [Cu5Cl6]− cluster (a, s3). The second one is the Cu6Cl6 cluster with hexagonal prism-like configuration (e). Notably, six Cu and six chloride atoms alternatively occupy the vertices of the hexagonal prism, and the two face-to-face six-membered Cu3Cl3 chair rings were alternatively arranged. Two hmt ligands play different roles: the hmt1 ligand links four [Cu5Cl6]− cluster (b), while the hmt2 links three Cu6Cl6 and one [Cu5Cl6]− clusters (d).
elements.clean_text: The single-crystal structure analysis shows that compound 2 includes two different types of CuCl clusters. Similar to 1, four Cu atoms are bridged by six Cl atoms to produce a [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster, and then three chloride atoms chelate to another Cu3 atom to form the [Cu5Cl6]- cluster (a, s3). The second one is the Cu6Cl6 cluster with hexagonal prism-like configuration (e). Notably, six Cu and six chloride atoms alternatively occupy the vertices of the hexagonal prism, and the two face-to-face six-membered Cu3Cl3 chair rings were alternatively arranged. Two hmt ligands play different roles: the hmt1 ligand links four [Cu5Cl6]- cluster (b), while the hmt2 links three Cu6Cl6 and one [Cu5Cl6]- clusters (d).

elements.content: (a) The defined 5-connected node of [Cu5Cl6]− cluster; (b) the 4-connected node of hmt1 ligand; (c) the topology of the bilayer; (d) the 4-connected node of hmt2 ligand; (e) the defined 6-connected node of Cu6Cl6 cluster; (f) the topology of the kgd-type 2D layer; (g) the whole framework; and (h) the topology of 2. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) The defined 5-connected node of [Cu5Cl6]- cluster; (b) the 4-connected node of hmt1 ligand; (c) the topology of the bilayer; (d) the 4-connected node of hmt2 ligand; (e) the defined 6-connected node of Cu6Cl6 cluster; (f) the topology of the kgd-type 2D layer; (g) the whole framework; and (h) the topology of 2. The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The prominent structural feature of 2 is that it has a 3D framework based on two different layer-like substructures. At first, without consideration of the Cu3 atom of the [Cu5Cl6]− cluster, the [Cu4Cl6]2– cluster is linked by three hmt1 ligands. The hmt1 ligand also coordinates to three [Cu4Cl6]2– clusters. In this way, the [Cu4Cl6]2– clusters and hmt1 ligands cross-link each other to form a 3-connected graphite-like layer. In fact, the Cu3 atom is enclosed in the [Cu5Cl6]− cluster. The attendance of Cu3 atom combines two graphite-like layers to one bilayer, which can be reduced as 4-connected net with the point symbol of (43.63) (c). In addition, each Cu6Cl6 cluster is connected by six hmt2 ligands, and each hmt2 links three Cu6Cl6 clusters to form a (3,6)-connected kgd-type layer (f). Then such two kinds of layers were alternatively linked by hmt2 ligands through a Cu4–N bond to form a final 3D framework (g). As far as we know, no such structural feature has been observed previously in cluster-based framework compounds. To simplify this complex structure, topological analysis was performed by the Topospro program. Two hmt ligands can be reduced as two tetrahedral four-connected nodes; the [Cu5Cl6]− cluster acts as a five-connected node, and the Cu6Cl6 cluster acts as six-connected node. The whole framework can be specified by a 4,4,5,6-connected net with the point symbol of (43.63)4(43.66.8)2­(46.66.83) (h).
elements.clean_text: The prominent structural feature of 2 is that it has a 3D framework based on two different layer-like substructures. At first, without consideration of the Cu3 atom of the [Cu5Cl6]- cluster, the [Cu4Cl6]2- cluster is linked by three hmt1 ligands. The hmt1 ligand also coordinates to three [Cu4Cl6]2- clusters. In this way, the [Cu4Cl6]2- clusters and hmt1 ligands cross-link each other to form a 3-connected graphite-like layer. In fact, the Cu3 atom is enclosed in the [Cu5Cl6]- cluster. The attendance of Cu3 atom combines two graphite-like layers to one bilayer, which can be reduced as 4-connected net with the point symbol of (43.63) (c). In addition, each Cu6Cl6 cluster is connected by six hmt2 ligands, and each hmt2 links three Cu6Cl6 clusters to form a (3,6)-connected kgd-type layer (f). Then such two kinds of layers were alternatively linked by hmt2 ligands through a Cu4-N bond to form a final 3D framework (g). As far as we know, no such structural feature has been observed previously in cluster-based framework compounds. To simplify this complex structure, topological analysis was performed by the Topospro program. Two hmt ligands can be reduced as two tetrahedral four-connected nodes; the [Cu5Cl6]- cluster acts as a five-connected node, and the Cu6Cl6 cluster acts as six-connected node. The whole framework can be specified by a 4,4,5,6-connected net with the point symbol of (43.63)4(43.66.8)2(46.66.83) (h).

elements.content: The main feature of 3 is that it has 4-connected dia-type 3D framework based on a 41 helical chain. In 3, both Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are tetrahedrally coordinated by three chloride atoms and one N atom from the hmt ligand (Figure s4). All the chloride atoms and hmt act as μ2-bridge ligands. The third N site of hmt is coordinated to Cu3 atom, which is two coordinated, and the water molecule is pendent on it. Two Cu atoms are bridged by two Cl atoms to produce a [Cu2Cl2] four-membered ring (a), and the third Cl atom was coordinated to the Cu atom to form a [Cu2Cl3] unit. Then these [Cu2Cl3] units are connected to each other to generate a 41 helical chain running along the c-axis (c). To the best of our knowledge, the above-mentioned helical chain represented the first 41 helical chain based on an anionic copper halide unit. Such one-dimensional (1D) chain is further connected by hmt ligands to form the final framework. By considering the [Cu2Cl3] as four-connected nodes, the hmt as well as the chloride atom as linkers (b), this framework could be simplified as a 4-connected dia network (d).
elements.clean_text: The main feature of 3 is that it has 4-connected dia-type 3D framework based on a 41 helical chain. In 3, both Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are tetrahedrally coordinated by three chloride atoms and one N atom from the hmt ligand (Figure s4). All the chloride atoms and hmt act as μ2-bridge ligands. The third N site of hmt is coordinated to Cu3 atom, which is two coordinated, and the water molecule is pendent on it. Two Cu atoms are bridged by two Cl atoms to produce a [Cu2Cl2] four-membered ring (a), and the third Cl atom was coordinated to the Cu atom to form a [Cu2Cl3] unit. Then these [Cu2Cl3] units are connected to each other to generate a 41 helical chain running along the c-axis (c). To the best of our knowledge, the above-mentioned helical chain represented the first 41 helical chain based on an anionic copper halide unit. Such one-dimensional (1D) chain is further connected by hmt ligands to form the final framework. By considering the [Cu2Cl3] as four-connected nodes, the hmt as well as the chloride atom as linkers (b), this framework could be simplified as a 4-connected dia network (d).

elements.content: (a) The defined 4-connected node of [Cu2Cl2] cluster; (b) the hmt ligand as the linker; (c) the 41 helical chain constructed by a [(Cu2Cl3)+] unit; (d) the dia topology of 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) The defined 4-connected node of [Cu2Cl2] cluster; (b) the hmt ligand as the linker; (c) the 41 helical chain constructed by a [(Cu2Cl3)+] unit; (d) the dia topology of 3.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that 4 crystallizes in a orthorhombic space group Pnma and contains four copper atoms, two chloride atoms, one hmt ligand, one CN–, and two coordinated water molecules (Figure s5). Both Cu1 and Cu3 atoms are tetrahedrally coordinated by two chloride atoms, one N atom from CN, and one from the hmt ligand. The Cu2 atom is two coordinated, and the water molecule is pendent on it. The Cu4 atom also adopts a tetrahedral coordination, besides two chloride atoms, one N atom from CN–, and one water molecule is pendent on it. All the chloride atoms act as μ2-bridge ligands. All the N atoms of the hmt ligand coordinate to the Cu atoms. Four Cu atoms are bridged by four Cl atoms to produce an [Cu4Cl4] eight-membered ring (a). Four Cu atoms lie on one plane, and all four μ2-Cl ions were located above the plane, featuring a crown-like shape. The bidentate CN– ligand adopts a μ4-bridging mode. The nitrogen atom is simultaneously coordinated to three Cu atoms from one [Cu4Cl4] ring, generating the shortest Cu···Cu distance, 2.537 Å. The carbon atom is coordinated to the remaining Cu atom from one [Cu4Cl4] ring. In this way, the CN– acts as the linker to connect the [Cu4Cl4] eight-membered ring to form a zigzag chain along the a-axis (d,e), while the hmt acts as a μ3-bridge to link the [Cu4Cl4] to form a double zigzag chain (DZC) along the b-axis (c,f). Two such 1D structures cross-link each other by sharing the Cu4Cl4 cluster to form the final framework. By treating the [Cu4Cl4] and the hmt as nodes, this framework could be simplified as a (3,5)-connected network with the point symbol (42.65.83)­(42.6) (h).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that 4 crystallizes in a orthorhombic space group Pnma and contains four copper atoms, two chloride atoms, one hmt ligand, one CN-, and two coordinated water molecules (Figure s5). Both Cu1 and Cu3 atoms are tetrahedrally coordinated by two chloride atoms, one N atom from CN, and one from the hmt ligand. The Cu2 atom is two coordinated, and the water molecule is pendent on it. The Cu4 atom also adopts a tetrahedral coordination, besides two chloride atoms, one N atom from CN-, and one water molecule is pendent on it. All the chloride atoms act as μ2-bridge ligands. All the N atoms of the hmt ligand coordinate to the Cu atoms. Four Cu atoms are bridged by four Cl atoms to produce an [Cu4Cl4] eight-membered ring (a). Four Cu atoms lie on one plane, and all four μ2-Cl ions were located above the plane, featuring a crown-like shape. The bidentate CN- ligand adopts a μ4-bridging mode. The nitrogen atom is simultaneously coordinated to three Cu atoms from one [Cu4Cl4] ring, generating the shortest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance, 2.537 Å. The carbon atom is coordinated to the remaining Cu atom from one [Cu4Cl4] ring. In this way, the CN- acts as the linker to connect the [Cu4Cl4] eight-membered ring to form a zigzag chain along the a-axis (d,e), while the hmt acts as a μ3-bridge to link the [Cu4Cl4] to form a double zigzag chain (DZC) along the b-axis (c,f). Two such 1D structures cross-link each other by sharing the Cu4Cl4 cluster to form the final framework. By treating the [Cu4Cl4] and the hmt as nodes, this framework could be simplified as a (3,5)-connected network with the point symbol (42.65.83)(42.6) (h).

elements.content: Defined 5-connected node in 4 (a) and 5 (b); (c) the hmt ligand as the 3-connected node and (d) the CN– as the linker in 4 and 5; (e) the similar zigzag chain formed by CN– and CuCl clusters in 4 and 5; the hmt connected the CuCl cluster to form the double zigzag chain (DZC) in 4 (f) and 2D layer in 5 (g); the 3,5-connected topology in 4 (h) and 5 (i). The H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 4  Defined 5-connected node in 4 (a) and 5 (b); (c) the hmt ligand as the 3-connected node and (d) the CN- as the linker in 4 and 5; (e) the similar zigzag chain formed by CN- and CuCl clusters in 4 and 5; the hmt connected the CuCl cluster to form the double zigzag chain (DZC) in 4 (f) and 2D layer in 5 (g); the 3,5-connected topology in 4 (h) and 5 (i). The H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In comparison, compound 5 also has a (3,5)-connected framework based on the [Cu3Cl2] cluster. Two Cu atoms are bridged by two Cl atoms to produce a [Cu2Cl2] four-membered ring (b), and one Cl atom was coordinated to the third Cu atom to form a [Cu3Cl2] unit. Similarly, the CN– connects the [Cu3Cl2] cluster as the linker to form a zigzag chain along b-axis (d,e). Differently, the CN– ligand here adopts a μ3-bridging mode. The nitrogen atom is coordinated to two Cu atoms, generating the shortest Cu···Cu distance, 2.462 Å. The hmt also acts as a μ3-bridge, linking the [Cu3Cl2] to form a 2D fes-type layer (b,g). Then the 2D layer is pillared by the CN– to form the 3D framework. It could be treated as a (3,5)-connected network with the point symbol (4.62)­(4.67.82) (i).
elements.clean_text: In comparison, compound 5 also has a (3,5)-connected framework based on the [Cu3Cl2] cluster. Two Cu atoms are bridged by two Cl atoms to produce a [Cu2Cl2] four-membered ring (b), and one Cl atom was coordinated to the third Cu atom to form a [Cu3Cl2] unit. Similarly, the CN- connects the [Cu3Cl2] cluster as the linker to form a zigzag chain along b-axis (d,e). Differently, the CN- ligand here adopts a μ3-bridging mode. The nitrogen atom is coordinated to two Cu atoms, generating the shortest Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance, 2.462 Å. The hmt also acts as a μ3-bridge, linking the [Cu3Cl2] to form a 2D fes-type layer (b,g). Then the 2D layer is pillared by the CN- to form the 3D framework. It could be treated as a (3,5)-connected network with the point symbol (4.62)(4.67.82) (i).

elements.content: For these compounds, despite construction by both copper chloride clusters and the hmt ligand, various structures are formed due to the different multinuclear copper clusters (Cu2Cl3, Cu3Cl2, Cu4Cl4, Cu4Cl6, Cu5Cl6, and Cu6Cl6), varied coordination nodes of hmt (2-c, 3-c, and 4-c), and the different connection between them. As far as we know, only two oligomers based on hmt and Cu2Br2 or Cu4OCl6 clusters have been reported. In our work, via systematically optimizing the synthetic condition, 3D structures are produced, especially the rare zeolitic structure of compound 1. The result demonstrates that this strategy is very effective in the construction of novel MOFs.
elements.clean_text: For these compounds, despite construction by both copper chloride clusters and the hmt ligand, various structures are formed due to the different multinuclear copper clusters (Cu2Cl3, Cu3Cl2, Cu4Cl4, Cu4Cl6, Cu5Cl6, and Cu6Cl6), varied coordination nodes of hmt (2-c, 3-c, and 4-c), and the different connection between them. As far as we know, only two oligomers based on hmt and Cu2Br2 or Cu4OCl6 clusters have been reported. In our work, via systematically optimizing the synthetic condition, 3D structures are produced, especially the rare zeolitic structure of compound 1. The result demonstrates that this strategy is very effective in the construction of novel MOFs.

elements.content: The fluorescent properties of the as-synthesized compounds were studied in the solid state at room temperature (). Upon ultraviolet (UV) excitation at 350 nm, these compounds display yellow green emissions with a maximum at ca. 500–600 nm. In comparison, the free hmt ligand displays an emission centered at 485 nm under excitation at 320 nm. Compared to the organic ligand, all the emissions are red-shifted. Therefore, ligand-centered π → π* transitions could be discarded. We notice that the maximum emission wavelengths of them are as follows: λ5 (520 nm) < λ1 (550 nm) < λ3 (558 nm) < λ2 (596 nm). The size of the Cu–Cl clusters shows a similar trend, Cu3Cl2 (5) < Cu4Cl6 (1) < Cu5Cl6 (2) and Cu6Cl6 (2). So we assume that the main emissions in such compounds may probably be attributed to halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT). For such discrete clusters, the size of the cluster becomes bigger, and it is easier for XMCT. In them, compound 3 is a stranger; it has an infinite 1D Cu–Cl chain based on small repeated cluster Cu2Cl3, which is also helpful to XMCT. So the red-shift in 3 is much bigger than that in 5 and 1.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence Properties

The fluorescent properties of the as-synthesized compounds were studied in the solid state at room temperature (). Upon ultraviolet (UV) excitation at 350 nm, these compounds display yellow green emissions with a maximum at ca. 500-600 nm. In comparison, the free hmt ligand displays an emission centered at 485 nm under excitation at 320 nm. Compared to the organic ligand, all the emissions are red-shifted. Therefore, ligand-centered π → π* transitions could be discarded. We notice that the maximum emission wavelengths of them are as follows: λ5 (520 nm) < λ1 (550 nm) < λ3 (558 nm) < λ2 (596 nm). The size of the Cu-Cl clusters shows a similar trend, Cu3Cl2 (5) < Cu4Cl6 (1) < Cu5Cl6 (2) and Cu6Cl6 (2). So we assume that the main emissions in such compounds may probably be attributed to halide to metal charge transfer (XMCT). For such discrete clusters, the size of the cluster becomes bigger, and it is easier for XMCT. In them, compound 3 is a stranger; it has an infinite 1D Cu-Cl chain based on small repeated cluster Cu2Cl3, which is also helpful to XMCT. So the red-shift in 3 is much bigger than that in 5 and 1.

elements.content: Emission spectra of compounds 1–3 and 5 and free hmt ligand in solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 5  Emission spectra of compounds 1-3 and 5 and free hmt ligand in solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: In summary, to assemble a tetrahedral hmt ligand and hmt-type Cu4Cl6 clusters, with the structure-directing effect of a 2D metal–organic complex, a 3D cluster organic framework of 1 with lon topology is successfully built. Moreover via modulation the synthetic condition, other four cluster organic frameworks based on this hmt ligand and different other copper-halide clusters are also reported. Among them, 2 is a 3D framework with 3,4,4,6-cononected topology constructured by Cu6Cl6 and Cu5Cl6 clusters. 3 is a dia topological framework based on 4-connected Cu2Cl3 clusters and 2-connected hmt ligand. Both 4 and 5 can be simiplified as 3,5-connected networks but based on different clusters, i.e., Cu4Cl4 and Cu3Cl2, respectively. Owing to the different connections between the various copper chloride clusters and hmt ligand, these structures exhibit diverse architectures. The photoluminescent studies reveal that they are fluorescent with yellow-green light emission that originates from halide to metal charge transfer. These rich structures demonstrated here provide an effective synthetic method to construct copper halide cluster-based organic frameworks, and especially offer a possibility for those with zeolitic networks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, to assemble a tetrahedral hmt ligand and hmt-type Cu4Cl6 clusters, with the structure-directing effect of a 2D metal-organic complex, a 3D cluster organic framework of 1 with lon topology is successfully built. Moreover via modulation the synthetic condition, other four cluster organic frameworks based on this hmt ligand and different other copper-halide clusters are also reported. Among them, 2 is a 3D framework with 3,4,4,6-cononected topology constructured by Cu6Cl6 and Cu5Cl6 clusters. 3 is a dia topological framework based on 4-connected Cu2Cl3 clusters and 2-connected hmt ligand. Both 4 and 5 can be simiplified as 3,5-connected networks but based on different clusters, i.e., Cu4Cl4 and Cu3Cl2, respectively. Owing to the different connections between the various copper chloride clusters and hmt ligand, these structures exhibit diverse architectures. The photoluminescent studies reveal that they are fluorescent with yellow-green light emission that originates from halide to metal charge transfer. These rich structures demonstrated here provide an effective synthetic method to construct copper halide cluster-based organic frameworks, and especially offer a possibility for those with zeolitic networks.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of hmt (0.069 g, 0.5 mol), CuCl (0.098 g, 1.0 mmol), n-butanol (4.0 mL), and NH3·H2O (2.0 mL) was sealed in a 20 mL vial at 120 °C for 4 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-yellow crystals of 1 were obtained (Yield: 60%). IR (KBr cm–1): 3450 (m), 3243 (w), 2970 (w), 2888 (w), 1623 (w), 1463 (m), 1227 (s), 1005 (s), 693 (m), 650 (w). Elemental analysis for C12H31Cl6Cu7N8O4 (%): Calcd: C, 14.47; H, 3.09; N, 11.25. Found: C, 15.05; H, 3.18; N, 12.61.

Synthesis of [(Cu<sub>5</sub>Cl<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(Cu<sub>6</sub>Cl<sub>6</sub>)­(hmt)<sub>4</sub>]­(hmt-CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

a). The mixture of hmt (0.075 g, 0.5 mmol), CuCl (0.098 g, 1.0 mmol), and methanol (4.0 mL) were placed in a 20 mL vial at 80 °C for 7–10 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: 60%). IR (KBr cm–1): 3430 (w), 2984 (w), 2960 (w), 2890 (w), 1659 (w), 1453 (m), 1372 (w), 1235 (s), 1028 (s), 706 (m), 669 (m). Elemental analysis for C38H56Cl18Cu16N24O3 (%): Calcd: C, 17.88; H, 2.21; N, 13.17. Found: C, 18.05; H, 2.18; N, 13.61.

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>3</sub>Cl<sub>3</sub>(hmt)]­(H<sub>2</sub>O) (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of hmt (0.0692 g, 0.5 mmol), CuCl (0.0961g, 1.0 mmol), n-butanol (4.0 mL), and NH3·H2O (0.5 mL) was placed in a 20 mL vial at 120 °C for 7 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 3 were obtained (yield: 20%). IR (KBr cm–1): 3438 (w), 3289 (w), 2930 (w), 2888 (w), 1601 (m), 1452 (m), 1248 (s), 992 (s), 704 (w), 677 (m). Elemental analysis for C6H14Cl3Cu3N4O (%): Calcd: C, 15.83; H, 3.10; N, 12.31. Found: C, 16.53; H, 3.42; N, 12.87.

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>5</sub>Cl<sub>4</sub>(hmt)­(CN)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>4</bold>)

The mixture of hmt (0.069 g, 0.5 mmol), CuCl (0.095 g, 1.0 mmol), n-butanol (4.0 mL), and NH3·H2O (1.0 mL) were placed in a 20 mL vial at 100 °C for 5 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale, colorless block crystals of 4 were obtained just sufficient for a single crystal X-ray structure determination.

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>3</sub>Cl<sub>2</sub>(hmt)­(CN)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>5</bold>)

A mixture of hmt (0.069 g, 0.5 mmol), CuCl (0.095 g, 1.0 mmol), n-butanol (4.0 mL), and NH3·H2O (0.28 mL) were placed in a 20 mL vial at 100 °C for 12 days and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 5 were obtained (yield: 30%). IR (KBr cm–1): 3315 (m), 3236 (w), 2968 (w), 2884 (w), 2035 (m), 1607 (w), 1463 (m), 1366 (w), 1242 (s), 1180 (m), 1010 (s), 703 (m), 664 (m). Elemental analysis for C7H14Cl2Cu3N5O (%): Calcd: C, 18.86; H, 3.16; N, 15.71. Found: C, 19.18; H, 3.38; N, 15.87.
